prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Effect of Transfer: Proceedings in the Transferee Court

para.paratext: Settlement is an important part of modern civil litigation and is one of the reasons for permitting liberal discovery. Pretrial conference procedure is intended, in part, to foster settlement discussions.[1] The role of the courts in the settlement process varies from jurisdiction to jurisdiction, judge to judge, and case to case. There is no absolute guide as to what is the proper level of the court's involvement in the settlement process,[2] but there is near-unanimous agreement that courts are actively involved in managing cases toward the end of settlement and that judicial involvement has some proper role.[3] Global settlement is a common result in MDL dockets, and the MDL process is often superior to class actions for resolving complex cases.[4]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
See Fed. R. Civ. P. 16. The role of settlement in litigation is discussed in David F. Herr, Roger S. Haydock & Jeffrey W. Stempel, Fundamentals of Pretrial Litigation§§ 14.1–14.6 (10th ed. 2016).

Legal theorists and legal practitioners do not agree on the proper role of trial judges in the settlement process. Some scholars believe that judges should be limited to the traditional role of adjudicating discrete matters brought before them by the parties for resolution. See, e.g., Judith Resnik, Managerial Judges, 96 Harv. L. Rev. 374 (1982). Many lawyers believe that judges should become involved in the settlement process and that judges can better assist in the resolution of disputes by confronting the entire dispute rather than the narrow legal issues submitted to them for resolution by the parties. See, e.g., Hon. Donald P. Lay, A Blueprint for Judicial Management, 17 Creighton L. Rev. 1047 (1984); Federal Judge as a Case Manager: The New Role in Guiding a Case From Filing to Disposition, 69 Calif. L. Rev. 770 (1981); Hon. William W Schwarzer, Managing Civil Litigation: The Trial Judge's Role, 61 Judicature 400 (1978).

See, e.g., William W Schwarzer, Managing Civil Litigation: The Trial Judge's Role, 61 Judicature 400 (1978). But see Owen Fiss, Against Settlement, 93 Yale L.J. 1073 (1984) (author critical of settlement regardless of process giving rise to it).

See generally Eldon E. Fallon, Jeremy T. Grabill & Robert Pitard Wynne, Bellwether Trials in Multidistrict Litigation, 82 Tul. L. Rev. 2323 (2008); Edward F. Sherman, The MDL Model for Resolving Complex Litigation if a Class Action is Not Possible, 82 Tul. L. Rev. 2205, 2209–16 (2008).
